name: Always, Sometimes, Never
description: Children evaluate a mathematical statement and decide whether it is always true, sometimes true, or never true. They must provide examples or counterexamples to justify their answer. Develops the ability to generalise, test conjectures, and construct logical arguments. One of the NCETM's core reasoning structures.
question_template: Is this statement always true, sometimes true, or never true? {mathematical_statement}. Prove it.

example_questions.question: When you add two odd numbers, the answer is even. Always, sometimes, or never?
A multiple of 4 is also a multiple of 2. Always, sometimes, or never?
When you multiply a number by 10, you add a zero. Always, sometimes, or never?
A square number has an odd number of factors. Always, sometimes, or never?

agent_prompt: Always-Sometimes-Never questions require children to test a generalisation. The key teaching move: when a child says 'always', ask 'can you find a case where it is NOT true?' When they say 'sometimes', ask 'when IS it true and when ISN'T it?' When they say 'never', ask 'are you absolutely sure — have you tried every type of number?' Choose statements where 'sometimes' is the answer for the richest discussion. Avoid statements that are trivially always or never true. For Y3-Y4, use statements about number properties (odd/even, multiples). For Y5-Y6, use statements about fractions, decimals, and algebra. IMPORTANT: do not present this format before Y3 — the logical distinction between 'always' and 'sometimes' is developmentally challenging for younger children.

name: Spot the Mistake
description: Children are shown a worked example containing a deliberate error. They must identify the mistake, explain why it is wrong, and correct it. Develops error analysis, precision, and the ability to reason about procedures rather than just execute them.
question_template: {child_name} says {incorrect_statement_or_working}. What mistake have they made? Can you correct it?

example_questions.question: Sam says half of 14 is 6. What mistake has Sam made?
A pupil writes 347 + 285 = 5212 using column addition. What has gone wrong?
Mia says 3/4 is smaller than 3/8 because 8 is bigger than 4. What is wrong with Mia's thinking?
Jake calculated 4.7 x 10 = 4.70. What mistake has Jake made?
A pupil simplifies 4/6 to 2/4. Explain the error and correct it.

agent_prompt: Spot the Mistake questions develop critical analysis of mathematical procedures. Choose errors that represent COMMON MISCONCEPTIONS, not random arithmetic mistakes. The pedagogical value is in diagnosing WHY the error occurred, not just that it is wrong. Always ask three things: (1) What is the mistake? (2) Why do you think they made it? (3) What should the correct answer be? Use fictional child names (Sam, Mia, Jake) to depersonalise the error. Never use the name of the actual child being taught. For Y1-Y2, use simple calculation errors. For Y3-Y4, use place value and procedural errors. For Y5-Y6, use conceptual errors (e.g. multiplying decimals by 10 'adds a zero').
source: NCETM Mastery PD Materials; White Rose Maths

name: Odd One Out
description: Children are given three or four numbers, shapes, or expressions and must identify which is the odd one out and explain why. The power of this format: there can be MORE THAN ONE valid answer with different reasoning. Develops flexible classification and justification.
question_template: Which is the odd one out: {item_a}, {item_b}, {item_c}? Why? Can you find a DIFFERENT odd one out with a different reason?

example_questions.question: Which is the odd one out: 2, 5, 8? (2 and 8 are even; 5 is odd. OR: 5 is a multiple of 5; 2 and 8 are not.)
Which is the odd one out: 12, 15, 20? (15 is odd; 12 and 20 are even. OR: 20 is not a multiple of 3; 12 and 15 are.)
Which is the odd one out: 0.5, 1/2, 50%? (Trick question — they are all equivalent! OR: 0.5 is a decimal, 1/2 is a fraction, 50% is a percentage — odd one out by notation.)
Which is the odd one out: 16, 25, 36? (25 is odd; 16 and 36 are even. OR: all are square numbers — no odd one out on that criterion.)

agent_prompt: Odd One Out develops flexible mathematical thinking. The key: THERE IS NO SINGLE CORRECT ANSWER. Any item can be the odd one out with the right reasoning. Always ask 'can you find a DIFFERENT odd one out with a DIFFERENT reason?' This pushes children beyond their first answer. For Y1-Y2: use numbers with obvious properties (odd/even, size). For Y3-Y4: use numbers with multiple properties (multiples, factors, primes). For Y5-Y6: use numbers/expressions that can be classified by type (fraction/decimal/percentage) or by value. Accept any answer with valid mathematical reasoning.

name: True or False
description: Children evaluate a mathematical statement and explain whether it is true or false, giving a proof or counterexample. Simpler than Always-Sometimes-Never because the answer is binary, making it suitable from Y1. Develops the habit of checking rather than assuming.
question_template: True or false: {mathematical_statement}. Explain how you know.

example_questions.question: True or false: 8 + 5 = 12.
True or false: A square has 4 right angles.
True or false: 3 x 4 = 4 x 3. Explain why.
True or false: 0.3 is bigger than 0.29.
True or false: If you double the radius of a circle, you double the area.

agent_prompt: True or False is the simplest reasoning format. For Y1-Y2, the focus is on checking a calculation ('is this right or wrong?'). From Y3, shift to conceptual statements that require explanation, not just checking. Always ask 'how do you know?' — the explanation is more important than the answer. For false statements, ask the child to correct it. Choose statements where the false ones are commonly believed misconceptions (e.g. '0.3 < 0.29 because 29 > 3' is a classic decimal misconception).

name: Convince Me (Prove It)
description: Children make a mathematical claim and must convince the teacher (or a partner) that it is true. Develops formal justification and proof skills. The progression: Y3-Y4 'show me with examples', Y5 'explain why it must always work', Y6 'prove it using algebra or logical argument'.
question_template: Convince me that {mathematical_claim}. Can you explain WHY it works, not just THAT it works?

example_questions.question: Convince me that 24 is a multiple of both 3 and 4. Show me how you know.
Convince me that 1/3 is bigger than 1/4. Use a picture AND an explanation.
Convince me that the sum of three consecutive numbers is always a multiple of 3. Why does this work?
Convince me that the angles in a triangle always add up to 180 degrees. Can you prove it?

agent_prompt: Convince Me develops the critical distinction between showing (examples) and proving (logical argument). For Y3-Y4: accept examples and diagrams as evidence ('I tried 3+4+5=12 and 7+8+9=24, and both are multiples of 3'). For Y5: push for generalisation ('it works because the three numbers are n-1, n, and n+1, which add to 3n'). For Y6: expect structured arguments with some algebraic notation. IMPORTANT: do not present 'convince me' before Y3 — the meta-cognitive demand of constructing a deliberate argument is too high for Y1-Y2. Use 'True or False' or 'Spot the Mistake' for younger children.
source: NRICH (Convince yourself, convince a friend, convince a sceptic); NCETM

name: How Many Ways?
description: Children find multiple solutions to an open-ended problem. Develops systematic working, exhaustive thinking, and the ability to organise solutions to prove completeness. Connects to combinatorics in later years.
question_template: How many ways can you {mathematical_task}? How do you know you have found them all?

example_questions.question: How many ways can you make 10 using two numbers?
How many different rectangles can you draw on a 4x4 dot grid?
How many ways can you make 50p using only silver coins (5p, 10p, 20p, 50p)?
How many different nets can you draw for a cube?
How many ways can you arrange the digits 1, 2, 3, 4 to make a 4-digit number divisible by 4?

agent_prompt: How Many Ways develops systematic problem-solving. The key teaching question is not 'how many did you find?' but 'how do you know you have found them ALL?' This pushes children to work systematically rather than randomly. For Y1-Y2: accept listing by trial and error. From Y3: insist on a system ('I started with the biggest coin and worked down'). From Y5: expect organised recording (tables, lists) and reasoning about completeness. Always ask 'could there be more?' before confirming the child has found all solutions.

name: What If?
description: Children explore what happens when a condition is changed in a mathematical problem. Develops conjectural thinking, generalisation, and the ability to explore mathematical structure by varying parameters. The foundation of algebraic thinking.
question_template: You found that {original_result}. What if {changed_condition}? What would happen then? Why?

example_questions.question: You know 5 + 3 = 8. What if you added 1 more to each number? What would the answer be? Why?
3 x 4 = 12. What if you doubled one of the numbers? What happens to the answer?
You can make a square number by adding consecutive odd numbers: 1+3=4, 1+3+5=9. What if you kept going? What would be next?
The area of this rectangle is 24cm squared. What if you kept the area the same but made it twice as long? What would happen to the width?

agent_prompt: What If questions develop algebraic thinking by varying one parameter and observing the effect. The key: change ONE thing at a time. Say 'what STAYS the same and what CHANGES?' This is the scientific method applied to maths. For Y2-Y3: vary numbers in simple operations. For Y4-Y5: vary shapes (what if the triangle had a bigger base?), vary operations (what if you multiplied instead of added?). For Y6: vary algebraic relationships (what if x was negative?). Always follow up with 'can you predict what would happen if we changed it AGAIN?'

name: What Comes Next?
description: Children identify and extend patterns or sequences, then explain the rule. Develops pattern recognition, generalisation, and the seeds of algebraic thinking (finding the nth term). One of the earliest mathematical reasoning activities.
question_template: Look at this pattern: {sequence}. What comes next? How do you know? Can you describe the rule?

example_questions.question: 2, 4, 6, 8, ... What comes next? What is the rule?
1, 4, 9, 16, ... What comes next? What are these numbers called?
3, 7, 11, 15, ... What comes next? What is the rule? Will 50 be in this sequence?
1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, ... What comes next? How is each number made from the ones before it?

agent_prompt: What Comes Next builds pattern recognition. The progression: Y1-Y2 describe the pattern in words ('add 2 each time'). Y3-Y4 test whether a given number will appear in the sequence ('will 50 be in the sequence 3, 7, 11, 15...?'). Y5-Y6 express the rule algebraically ('the nth term is 4n - 1'). Always ask THREE questions: (1) what comes next? (2) what is the rule? (3) will [number] be in the sequence? The third question requires applying the rule, not just extending the pattern.
source: NCETM; National Curriculum Programme of Study

name: Same and Different
description: Children compare two numbers, shapes, expressions, or representations and identify similarities and differences. Develops precise mathematical vocabulary and the ability to attend to mathematical structure rather than surface features.
question_template: What is the same about {item_a} and {item_b}? What is different? Can you find something else that is the same? Something else that is different?

example_questions.question: What is the same and what is different about a square and a rectangle?
What is the same and what is different about 3/4 and 3/8?
What is the same and what is different about 24 x 3 and 12 x 6?
What is the same and what is different about 2:3 and 4:6?

agent_prompt: Same and Different develops precise mathematical language. The key: push beyond the obvious. If a child says 'they are both numbers', ask 'what MATHEMATICAL property do they share?' Prompt for structural similarities: 'they are both even', 'they both equal 72', 'they are both composed of the same prime factors.' For shapes: push beyond 'they both have 4 sides' to 'they both have 2 pairs of parallel sides.' Always ask for MULTIPLE similarities and differences — the first answer is rarely the most mathematically interesting one.
source: NCETM Mastery PD Materials; Craig Barton 'Diagnostic Questions'

name: Would You Rather?
description: Children choose between two mathematical options and justify their choice with calculation and reasoning. E.g. 'Would you rather have 1/3 of 60 sweets or 1/4 of 100 sweets?' Develops estimation, comparison, and the ability to make and justify decisions using mathematics.
question_template: Would you rather {option_a} or {option_b}? Why? Show your working to prove your choice is better.

example_questions.question: Would you rather have 3 bags of 5 sweets or 2 bags of 8 sweets?
Would you rather have 1/3 of 60 sweets or 1/4 of 100 sweets?
Would you rather have 25% of 200 pounds or 30% of 150 pounds?
Would you rather have a 20% discount on 50 pounds or a 15% discount on 70 pounds?

agent_prompt: Would You Rather makes maths purposeful by framing calculation as decision-making. IMPORTANT safeguarding note: avoid contexts that assume wealth or material privilege. Use 'sweets' or 'stickers' not 'money you can keep.' The mathematical value is in the COMPARISON, not the context. Always ask 'how much better is your choice?' after the child decides. For Y2-Y3: use simple multiplication or fraction-of-amount comparisons. For Y5-Y6: use percentage and ratio comparisons where the answer is not obvious by estimation. The best Would You Rather questions are ones where the answer surprises the child.
source: White Rose Maths; John Stevens 'Would You Rather Math'

name: Missing Number (Find the Unknown)
description: Children find a missing value in an equation or relationship. The earliest form of algebraic thinking: the box or blank represents an unknown. Progresses from missing addends (Y1) to missing factors (Y3) to algebraic unknowns (Y6).
question_template: {equation_with_blank}. What is the missing number? How did you work it out?

example_questions.question: 7 + ___ = 10. What is the missing number?
___ - 15 = 23. What is the missing number?
___ x 6 = 42. What is the missing number? How did you find it?
3x + 7 = 22. What is x?

agent_prompt: Missing Number problems are the foundation of algebraic thinking. The key: teach the child to REASON about the relationship, not to guess and check. For addition: 'what goes with 7 to make 10?' (using number bonds). For multiplication: 'what times 6 makes 42?' (using the inverse). For Y1-Y2: use a box or blank line for the unknown. From Y5: introduce letter notation (n, then x). Always ask HOW the child found the answer — the strategy matters more than the number. Common error: children treat the equals sign as 'the answer comes next' rather than 'both sides are the same.' Use missing number problems to correct this: 10 = 7 + ___ (equals sign on the left).
source: National Curriculum Programme of Study; NCETM

name: Explain Your Reasoning
description: Children are asked to explain WHY a mathematical fact is true or HOW they solved a problem, using words, diagrams, or symbols. The meta-prompt that can be applied to any mathematical task. Develops metacognition and mathematical communication.
question_template: {mathematical_task}. Explain your reasoning using words, pictures, or numbers.

example_questions.question: How do you know that 8 is more than 5? Explain.
How did you work out 47 + 38? Explain your method step by step.
Why is 1/3 equivalent to 2/6? Explain using a diagram.
The mean of five numbers is 12. One number is removed and the mean becomes 10. What was the number removed? Explain your reasoning.

agent_prompt: Explain Your Reasoning is the meta-prompt: it can follow ANY mathematical task. The progression of explanation quality: Y1-Y2 children explain in words ('I counted on my fingers'). Y3-Y4 children use mathematical vocabulary and diagrams ('I partitioned 47 into 40 and 7, then added 40+30=70 and 7+8=15'). Y5-Y6 children use formal mathematical notation and logical connectives ('since... therefore... because...'). IMPORTANT: accept and validate explanation at the child's current level — do not insist on formal language from a Y2 child. But always model the next level up: 'you said you put them together — in maths we call that adding or finding the total.'
source: NCETM Teaching for Mastery; National Curriculum aims
